response.answer_text: If it wasn’t Ashton Hennessy who asked the question, I would probably have given a snootier answer. Probably the most conspicuous of the modern theological perversities and abuses is of the term ‘racism’. ‘Racism’ is a retroactively defined phenomenon, in light of the theories of the nineteenth century and the political events of the twentieth. Prejudice, soft and heavy, on every subject was not the exception but the rule in the pre-modern world, where only theological thought was regulated, but not that of social life. Social life itself may have been—but not theories about which social faux pas’s are in fact the spiritual ones. The racialism of the late nineteenth century hit a declining culture like a perfect storm. The spiritual vacuum preceded the political one, and religious nationalism gives way only too easily to racialism, which is not even a refutation of its legitimacy, but just such an obvious and inevitable workplace hazard. The savageries of the holes in the state and church’s collective efforts to provide for the community were suddenly losing their theological ‘cover’, and the awkwardness of the intense and truly spiritualized inequality of Europe’s world order were worsening just as that cover was slipping. The ‘theologized’ racism of the era was not so much more easily dismissible than any other political heresy, certainly not before the World Wars; and it offered an effortless spirituality alongside a license to pillage. People calling not only mere prejudice ‘racism’, but trotting it out as a lever with which to gauge the acceptability of someone’s thought is like the Monty Python level depths of the Medieval excesses. It’s not really my style to include photos, but look at some of photographs of the death camps made by the liberating armies. That is what racism is; it is grotesque to be flippant about or wield it as a rhetorical weapon. Even by his own standards, many of Nietzsche’s remarks on most ‘populations’ are best understood as almost tongue in cheek, not at all because he was not serious, but because his ferocity was a quirk of his shtick; in part true to who he was, but in larger part a feature of a lingering desperation to be cute, clever, understood, admired, exactly as he knows just that is impossible. So was he kind of jerky, wildly prejudicial even by the standards of the time, even, I dare say, a bit Germanically c*nty? Certainly. But the question of whether Nietzsche harbored a categorical hatred of Africans, Asians, Semites, or anyone else does not bear examination. Nietzsche lived, fatally, in a world of abstractions; and he really did see these categories as closer to fictional characters in the drama of history, rather than working models of what any human being was likely to be.
